review_title: Bogged down by nepotism and petty politics
pros: Passionate colleagues who are dedicated to the charity's mission and working hard to put people with Parkinson's at the heart of their work. There are a lot of learning opportunities to better understand the condition and the challenges that people with Parkinson's face. There's a good training budget to help you grow your skillset.
cons: Nepotism and unfair practice run through the veins of this charity but unfortunately the CEO is too busy mercilessly axeing jobs and boasting about her jogging ventures to notice what goes on beneath her nose. Then again, it could be a chicken/egg situation. Ie have the new leadership and senior level changes spurred this unpleasant culture? Many colleagues think so, as the atmosphere at Parkinson's UK massively soured after the old CEO left and new leadership took the reins. A running joke at Parkinson's UK is how there's a ridiculous excess of line managers because people hire their favourites to management positions. I'm not saying this applies to everyone, but there are a lot of managers with a worrying lack of management experience and in some cases, employment and life experience. This has opened up a culture of bad leadership which lower level employees are lumbered with and have to bear the brunt of. In a lot of teams there's one person managing another person. This makes no sense especially in very small teams. Either the CEO and big cheeses haven't noticed this, or they just turn a blind eye and don't think it's important enough to challenge. Because there's such a culture of nepotism, there's very little opportunity for people to develop in their roles and be given fair opportunity for promotion (unless as I said, you are a favourite). This is why so many people end up leaving. They don't want to stick around in an environment where they don't feel valued or appreciated. It's been sad to see many talented colleagues who had so much potential leave because of this reason. There have also been many redundancies at the charity in the last month. This has made the atmosphere very unpleasant and shown a very horrible side of colleagues who were/are worried about losing their jobs. If you come to work to work, and not get swept up in petty politics and power trips, this might not be the place for you. Many longtime colleagues reminisce about the glory days with the old CEO Steve and how they wish he had stayed. He was a much admired and human CEO who made an effort to know his staff by name and treat everyone respectfully, no matter what level they worked at. This created a really lovely working environment and high levels of morale among staff. It's very sad to see this old atmosphere change completely and turn the opposite way.

review_title: Used to be great, now toxic and corporate
pros: Some great colleagues who are passionate and driven about the cause, good location and flexi-hours policy.
cons: As another reviewer has expressed, Parkinson's UK was a great place to work until the new CEO joined and made copious changes - for the worst- alongside dismantling a once positive working culture and turning it into a thoroughly unpleasant and corporate-like environment. This has created a toxic culture, especially among managers, while their lower-level staff are unfairly made to bear the brunt of whatever pressures they are facing from the top. This has resulted in some highly ruthless and unfair behaviour. Parkinson's UK used to be a joy to work at with the old CEO, but the new leadership has fostered a depressing and stifling working atmosphere, which has seen so many decent and talented colleagues leaving at an alarming rate. I sadly decided to leave because it became too unbearable and, like many, was fed up of the lack of opportunity to progress.

pros: Flexi time, opportunity to work with people with Parkinson’s and improve lives and outcomes.
cons: Have to go to office twice/week, long meetings, refusal to do things online to reduce travel Constant changes to business, no time to bed anything in and it’s all changed again. Lack of trust in Senior Leadership Management say one thing and then do the opposite Very low Morale Constant fear of redundancy Becoming very corporate in outlook Very toxic environment and colleagues will throw each other under a bus because everyone is afraid their job is next for the chop.

pros: A charity driven by people who are passionate and dedicated about helping people with Parkinson’s. You feel like you’re making a worthwhile contribution to a very important cause. There are many opportunities to meet people with the condition and understand first hand how it affects them and what needs to change. There are plenty of opportunities to grow your skillset and learn about other areas of the charity.
cons:
It would be ignorant of me to ignore the big elephant in the room: job instability. In the past few weeks, two notable members of staff were made redundant, and this has naturally instilled a widespread feeling of fear and unease among many remaining staff. I have no doubt that this recent chop was merely the tip of the iceberg and that many more redundancies will likely follow in the coming year. 

At the helm of the charity is a neurotic CEO who has a habit of chopping and changing things without giving her decisions due thought. She hasn’t done a great deal to ingratiate herself with staff members either. Many have been at the receiving end of her frosty and arguably haughty demeanour. She’ll only acknowledge you if occupy a higher level within the charity, otherwise she’ll just stare right through you, like you don’t exist. This has created a frosty and unpleasant atmosphere, which has personally put me off coming into the office, and opting to work from home instead. She also has a giant wallchart of the entire organisational structure in her office. No doubt she spends a great deal of time surveying this chart and deciding who’ll be next to get the chop. 

Talking of working from home, the CEO also enforced a strict “two day a week” working policy in April, which opened the floodgates to many staff exiting the charity. While I personally had no reservations about the new policy, it seems odd to me that it’s completely fallen by the wayside as hardly anyone (including management) currently abide by it. It just makes you wonder/lament how many staff needlessly left the charity in recent months. As I said, the CEO has a very changeable temperament, coupled with constantly shifting priorities, which doesn’t inspire great confidence.

review_title: Great work environment but lack of opportunity is an issue
pros:
Parkinson's UK is one of the few charities I've worked at that practises what it preaches (eg is committed to its organisational values and adheres to a zero bullying policy).

Flexible working, even before the pandemic.

Friendly staff culture and colleagues who are really committed to the cause.

A rigorous onboarding process: staff are fully encouraged and invited to Parkinson's awareness and skills based training sessions.
cons:
As is true of many charities, there are very limited opportunities for progression within Parkinson's UK or scope to really spread your wings and prove your true capabilities. An issue I had was feeling pigeon-holed in my role. Don't get me wrong - there were a few opportunities to dip into other teams and learn new skills, but these felt far and few between (at least on my team. This may not be true of others). It felt like a lot of interesting/large-scale work and projects were outsourced to freelancers, rather than being allocated to current staff, who could well have fitted them alongside their BAU workload. What frustrated me most was not being told about said projects until my head of dept would suddenly spring  on my team members that they even existed, and that extra resource was being allocated to work on them. This was down to the presumption that we were too busy with our BAU work - the operative word being "presumption". It would have been nice to have been consulted beforehand and asked if we would like to be involved in said projects/whether they might impinge on our existing workload. This felt like a big waste of resource and current talent within the charity, which felt quite undermining. 

Siloed working. Not a huge amount of collaboration across teams. I didn't really know what several other teams even did or about major projects they were working on.

Too many meetings. This ramped up during lockdown, which I guess happened across a lot of organisations. Mainly meetings that could have been emails. There was a lot of chopping and changing of meetings and meetings being called off at very short notice, which became quite annoying and bad form.

job_title: Parkinson's Local Adviser in Lisnarrick, Northern Ireland
pros:
I have just recently reached the amazing milestone of 20 years service within Parkinson's UK, and what an amazing journey it's been. The element that stands out the most for me as I look back over the years are the many wonderful people that I've met who have been affected by Parkinson's - how they have inspired me so much in coping with the sometimes very complex challenges of the condition within their everyday lives.
As I reflect back, I do really feel proud to have been able to support so many on this journey through the vital work that I have done, and continue to do within my role at Parkinson's UK. I am immensely proud of the united approach, and the impact of all our work within the charity, and I very much look forward in being part of it in the future.
I've seen how the charity has grown and developed so much in this time span, and I'm delighted that I've been part of the evolution. I don't really mind change - I think it is a necessary and  healthy thing for any organisation, and I really do feel privileged to have been a part of it all. I feel truly honoured to be working as part of an amazing group of people within the NI Team, who are such an inspiring, supportive and fun group of individuals. This extends to my colleagues within the  different areas of work throughout Parkinson's UK  whom I feel very connected to and supported by, through all of our many different roles.
cons: I honestly don't have any to share.

pros:
Flexible working, creative environment, engaged management, freedom to develop and deliver work outside business as usual, rewarding, the right amount of support, learning and upskilling opportunities, amazing colleagues, work life balance, respect for the skills you bring to the organisation...I could go on.

There have been major changes in the time I've been with the organisation, they have been necessary for the growth of the organisation and delivery of ever more ambitious projects. For instance, efforts to incorporate digital transformation into all activities and investment in our infrastructure reflects the organisation's ability for forward thinking.

I think anyone at Parkinson's UK would agree the job comes with a certain level of satisfaction knowing you are helping others, and in my role I particularly enjoy meeting supporters and seeing first hand the difference we, as an organisation, make. I am proud of the level of involvement we incorporate within our working as an organisation, and even more so within in my team.
cons:
Really there are very few negatives to working at Parkinson's UK, and overall the pros far outweigh the cons. The organisation does, however, seem to be a tad top heavy, and, in my opinion, there are certain areas of the organisation that deserve more budget and others where savings could be made. However, ultimately I have confidence that the decisions being made come from an excellent senior leadership team and board of trustees.

I also believe internal comms hasn't quite hit the nail on the head yet. There are far too many different channels of communication which can impact on the effectiveness of cross directorial communications. Additionally, there is a lot or irrelevant comms, as such staying up to date with all that is happening in such a wide-reaching organisation can be challenging.

I can understand previous comments about changes to working environment and frustrations pay, but I believe they are not unique to Parkinson's UK. 

There does seem to be a high level of turnover, which is frustrating. Recruiting, in any organisation, is a pain, and there can be a loss of continuity and momentum as new recruits to get up to speed, but I believe this shows how much opportunity there is to take on new challenges and learn new skills. I would also agree that there is a meeting culture that could be addressed further.
